entry.title: SAP Build Apps: Getting data with â€œGet Record Collectionâ€ or maybe â€œHTTP Destination Requestâ€?
entry.content:
â€œGet Record Collectionâ€

The most common (and comfortable) way to get data from backend is to use â€œGet Record Collectionâ€ flow function. All we need to do is to install an integration with SAP system via its REST API using SAP BTP Destination.

 

 

 

If we enable the â€œAutogenerate configurationâ€ option during installation of the integration, we will get even definition of the data structure, ready to use as a template for data variables.

 

 

We can even easily add call parameters, which are to be added to the relative path as a query â€“ all we need is to add additional inputs in the entity definition:

 

These additional inputs will be automatically added in the relative path and in the test section of the data entity. And we can use these additional inputs to send additional parameters with the API call:

 

 

And, as data variable uses in fact â€œGet Record Collectionâ€ flow function in the background, we also can do the same with â€œGet Record Collectionâ€ flow function:

 

 

When â€œGet Record Collectionâ€ is not enough

Sometimes we need some additional information, not only the data itself â€“ we need access to the header of the backend response â€“ something the â€œGet Record Collectionâ€ flow function canâ€™t easily (if at all) provide. And this is the case with getting data from the SAP BTP Auditlog service I wrote about in the previous blog (SAP BTP Global Account audit logs using SAP BTP Auditlog service, SAP Build Apps and SAP Ai Core). The issue with the Auditlog service is hat it does not always send requested data in single run. If the response should contain more data, the Auditlog service will use â€œpagingâ€. It will send first portion (page) only, and you will have to request next portion of the answer data, and next one, till all the data is received.

How do we know that our application should request next page of data? Auditlog service, when paging is used, adds appropriate information in the response header. If all the data is sent without paging, there is no additional information in the header. But if next page is ready for sending, the Auditlog service will add â€œpagingâ€ field in the response header. This â€œpagingâ€ field has the following structure:

Paging: â€œhandle=<page id>â€

The value of the â€œPagingâ€ field looks like this:



As â€œGet Record Collectionâ€ flow function doesnâ€™t give us access to the response header in any simple way, the better option to get data from the SAP BTP Auditlog service is to use the â€œHTTP Destination Requestâ€ flow function, which gives access to both: data and headers the easy way.

How to use this header field? The logic should go as follows:

  1. Empty the variable containing the data to be displayed
  2. Request data with the â€œHTTP Destination Requestâ€ flow function
  3. Add the body of the response to the variable containing the data to be displayed
  4. If the â€œpagingâ€ field exists in the response header: send next request for data to the Auditlog, but this time add value of the â€œpagingâ€ field to the request path as the last parameter and jump back to step 3
  5. If the â€œpagingâ€ field doesnâ€™t exist in the response header: display the content of the variable containing data

The logic should look like this:

 

How to get access to the response header? Using a formula. We can use the â€œoutputs["HTTP Request"].resHeadersâ€ in the formula. As the header is a json, it is enough to know the names of fields in the header and then we can check if field exists in the header:

IS_UNDEFINED(outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging

This function returns â€œtrueâ€ if the field id undefined, otherwise it returns â€œfalseâ€.

And then, if we know that the field exists, we can get its value simply by its name like this:

outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging

in the â€œSet App Variableâ€ or â€œSet Page Variableâ€ flow function.

I use both functions in single formula in the â€œSet Page Variableâ€ flow function:

IF(IS_UNDEFINED(outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging), "no_paging", outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging)

If the â€œpagingâ€ field is not defined in the header, the formula sets â€œno_pagingâ€ as the variable value. But if the â€œpagingâ€ field is defined, the formula sets its value as the variable value.

entry.title: Empowering SAP Build Apps with SAP Translation Hub: Multilingual Support for Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
In todayâ€™s global business landscape, offering multilingual support is crucial for reaching a broader audience. SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Translation Hub, in combination with SAP Build Apps, provides a powerful, no-code solution for automating translations in web and mobile applications. This blog demonstrates how you can create a translation featureâ€”that can be embedded in SAP Service Cloud V2 environments or used as a standalone application.

In this blog, we'll demonstrate how to:

  • Translate case data dynamically using SAP Translation Hub APIs.
  • Integrate this logic in a low-code/no-code app built with SAP Build Apps.
  • Embed the translation component directly into SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2, or run it as a standalone app.

Prerequisite

  • SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2
  • SAP BTP Global Account with appropriate entitlements
  • SAP Build Apps subscription
  • Translation Hub service activation
  • Basic understanding of SAP integration patterns

The Business Scenario

Consider a typical service management case in an SAP environment where:

  • Service teams need to handle customer issues across different geographical regions
  • Customers submit cases in their native languages
  • Technical documentation and knowledge bases exist in multiple languages
  • Cross-functional teams require real-time translation capabilities for efficient collaboration

we can see how language barriers can impact service delivery when dealing with technical descriptions, customer communications, and knowledge base content.

Key Features Illustrated

  • Source Language Selection (e.g., English)
  • Target Language Selection (e.g., German)
  • Automatic, Manual, or Batch Translation
  • User-Friendly Interface for text input and output
  • Easy embedding into other SAP solutions

Application Development

  • Create new SAP Build Apps project
  • Design translation interface components
  • Implement Translation Hub API integration
  • Configure data bindings and workflows

Solution Architecture

Our multilingual solution combines three powerful SAP technologies:

1. SAP Translation Hub

  • Real-time translation capabilities for 10+ languages
  • Context-aware translations for technical terminology
  • Integration APIs for seamless embedding

2. SAP Build Apps

  • Low-code development platform for rapid application creation
  • Responsive design capabilities for multi-device support
  • Seamless integration with SAP systems and external APIs
  • Visual development environment for citizen developers

3. SAP Service Cloud Integration

  • Native connectivity to existing SAP service management systems
  • Real-time data synchronization

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide

Environment Setup

  • Provision SAP BTP subaccount
  • Enable required services (Build Apps, Translation Hub)
  • Configure authentication and authorization

SAP Translation Hub 

you can click on View Subscription to see your application access under Instances and Subscriptions. 

In Instances and Subscriptions, click the dots to open the menu and select Create Service Binding.

In the dialog, enter a binding name, such as demo-binding as the name of your service binding. Click Create to create the service binding.

The following file formats are supported:

Type Format
HTML*.html (UTF-8 encoding)
Microsoft Office*.docx, *.xlsx, *.pptx
Text*.txt (UTF-8 encoding)
XLIFFxliff1.2
PDF*.pdf
SubRip Subtitle*.srt
WebVTT (Web Video Text Track)*.vtt
 

SAP Document Translation API supports real-time file translation via:

  • FormData (HTML-style form submission)
  • RAW
  • JSON

Endpoint:
POST /api/v1/translation

ğŸ”§Key Parameters

Parameter Type Description

fileformDataFile to translate (optional).
sourceLanguagequeryLanguage code of the original text (optional â€“ auto-detect if omitted).
targetLanguagequeryLanguage code of the translated text (required).
strictModeboolean(Optional) Enforce structural tag consistency. Default: false.
modelstringChoose "default" (SAP MT) or "llm" (LLM-based translation). Default: default.

MIME Types Supported:

Common formats like .txt, .pdf, .docx, .html, .srt, .vtt, and more.

Sample curl request:

 

curl -X POST "$BASE_URL/api/v1/translation/?sourceLanguage=en-US&targetLanguage=de-DE" \ -H "Authorization: Bearer $XSUAA_TOKEN" \ -F 'file=@/Users/Documents/demo.txt'

Similarly we need to configure for SAP Build Apps

SAP Build Apps

This opens the SAP Build lobby.

Within the SAP Build lobby, click Create.

Click Application, and click Next.

 

 

Click Frontend, and click Next.

 
 
 
Click Web & Mobile Application, and click Next.
 

Name the new app by entering:

 

Field Value
NameTranslation Hub Application
DescriptionTranslation Hub 

Click Review.

 
On the Summary page, click Create.

 

Your SAP Build Apps project is created, and the default Home page is displayed. Once created, projects can be accessed again at any time from the SAP Build lobby.

Drag the Essentials like drop down ,container, button and input put and and adjust as per you requirement 

Invoke the Translation Hub API through a button click to fetch the case description using the Service Cloud V2 Case ID, and update the source language text accordingly

The preview looks as mentioned below for my requirement 

In SAP Build Apps, the case description is auto-populated by consuming the Service Cloud V2 API. This text can either be auto-translated or translated on demand with the click of a button using the integrated translation service.

Translation Hub

Conclusion

The combination of SAP Translation Hub and SAP Build Apps provides a powerful foundation for building multilingual enterprise applications. Whether deployed as an embedded component within existing SAP solutions or as a standalone application, this approach delivers:

  • Rapid Development: Low-code platform accelerates time-to-market
  • Enterprise Grade: Built on SAP's trusted cloud infrastructure
  • Scalable Architecture: Supports growth from pilot to global deployment
  • Cost Effective: Reduces development and operational costs
  • Future Ready: Positioned for emerging AI and ML capabilities

By breaking down language barriers in service management processes, organizations can deliver superior customer experiences, improve operational efficiency, and unlock new opportunities in global markets.

entry.title: Unlocking Multilingual Document Translation with SAP Build Apps + SAP Translation Hub
entry.content:
In our previous blog post, we explored how to enable text translation within SAP Build Apps using SAP Translation Hub, making apps more inclusive and globally accessible.

Now, letâ€™s take this a step further. What if you need to translate entire documentsâ€”like Word files, PDFs, or HTML content? In this post, weâ€™ll demonstrate how to integrate SAP Build Apps with SAP Translation Hub to create a document translation flowâ€”quickly, efficiently, and without writing extensive code.

ğŸ“–Story: One Quote, Two Languages â€” One Lost Deal?

Meet Alex, a sales manager at a global electronics company based in Germany. Heâ€™s chasing a big opportunity with a Japanese client. The quote is ready, the price is right â€” but itâ€™s in English. The client requests it in Japanese.

Alex scrambles. He asks a colleague for help. He copy-pastes parts of the quote into a translation tool. He worries about accuracy, especially with technical terms. Meanwhile, the competitor â€” who sent a native-language quote â€” wins the deal

Could this have been avoided? Absolutely.

Enter SAP Build Apps + SAP Translation Hub â€” a powerful no-code solution to translate sales quotes and documents instantly, either as a standalone tool or tightly integrated with SAP CX Sales Cloud.

ğŸ§° Prerequisites

To implement this solution, youâ€™ll need:

  • âœ…SAP BTP subaccount with access to:
    • SAP Build Apps
    • SAP Translation Hub (entitlement required)
  • âœ…SAP CX Sales Cloud (optional, for embedded use case)
  • âœ…Document format: PDF, DOCX, or HTML
  • âœ…BTP Destination or integration layer (CAP / SAP Integration Suite)

ğŸ¯Use Case: Quote Translation in SAP Sales Cloud

Sales teams often generate quotes in their default language. However, sending proposals in a customerâ€™s native language improves clarity, trust, and conversion rates.

Example:
A salesperson in Spain generates a quote in English and wants to send it to a client in Brazil. Using this solution, the salesperson uploads the quote, selects â€œPortuguese (Brazil)â€ as the target language, and receives a translated document â€” within seconds.

The translated document is then sent directly to the customer or attached to the Sales Cloud opportunity.

ğŸ› ï¸ How It Works

  1. Generate Quote (SAP CX Sales Cloud): Standard PDF/Word output from a quote process.
  2. Upload to SAP Build Apps: User uploads the file and selects target language.
  3. Translation via SAP Translation Hub: The file is translated via secure API calls.
  4. Return Translated File: File is returned as downloadable content or pushed back to SAP Sales Cloud in attachment Tab.

ğŸ”„ Deployment Options: Standalone or Integrated

Option 1: Standalone App (No SAP CX Required)

  • A universal tool for business users across sales, legal, procurement, etc.
  • Upload any business document and get instant translations.
  • Deploy via SAP Build Apps and BTP â€” no coding needed.
  • Useful even for companies not yet using SAP Sales Cloud.

Option 2: Embedded in SAP CX Sales Cloud

  • Add translation buttons directly in the Quote Object Page.
  • Automatically trigger translation after quote generation.
  • Store translated versions in the same quote  record.

ğŸ“ˆ Business Benefits

Benefit Standalone App SAP Sales Cloud Integration

BenefitStandalone AppSAP Sales Cloud Integration
ğŸŒGlobal content readinessâœ…Translate any documentâœ…Translate sales-specific content
ğŸ•’Fast time-to-quoteâœ…Instant translationâœ…Automated translation post-quote
ğŸ› ï¸ Low-code implementationâœ…Fully no-code UIâœ…Extendable via BTP/Events
ğŸ”Secure enterprise workflowâœ…Controlled via BTP authâœ…Audit-ready and version controlled
ğŸ“¦Reusable across teamsâœ…Any department can useâœ…Tight sales workflow integration

SAP Translation Hub - Document Translation - Overview

 

 

 

Benefit Standalone App SAP Sales Cloud Integration

Step By Step

Please create the destination with the necessary values.

Drag and drop the required components onto the user interface.

Fetch and bind available languages directly from the Translation Hub API

Upload the PDF file in English format from the local file system

After selecting the target language, click the "Translate" button to proceed.

Video

Until now, we explored the process as a standalone document. Now, letâ€™s look at how this can be embedded within the CX Sales Cloud V2 Quote :

  • ğŸ’¼Seamless Integration with CX Sales Cloud V2 Quote
    Embed the translation workflow directly into the quoting process.
  • ğŸ“„Sales Representative Uploads the Quote PDF
    The sales rep can upload a quote document in their native language.
  • ğŸŒAutomatic Translation to Desired Language
    The uploaded PDF is translated into the target language using SAP Translation Hub.
  • ğŸ“Translated Document Attached Automatically
    The translated PDF is added to the Attachments tab of the quote.
  • âœ‰ï¸Send via DocuSign for Digital Signature
    The finalized, translated quote is sent to the customer through DocuSign for e-signature.

Embed the above standardized document into the Sales Cloud V2 Quote document.

The document was originally shared via a standard email. This same method can also be utilized to initiate a DocuSign signature request

Architecture

SAP Sales Cloud 
                     â†“
SAP Build Apps UI (File Upload + Language )
                     â†“
BTP Integration (Destination)
                    â†“
SAP Translation Hub API (Document Translation)
                    â†“
Translated Quote Returned to Build App â†’ Uploaded back to Sales Cloud or emailed

ğŸ“Conclusion

Translating sales quotes and documents no longer needs to be a manual, error-prone, or time-consuming task. With the powerful combination of SAP Build Apps and SAP Translation Hub, businesses can easily deliver personalized, localized contentâ€”whether in a standalone translation portal or as an embedded feature within SAP Sales Cloud.

This solution empowers sales teams to communicate more effectively, close deals faster, and build stronger relationships with global customersâ€”all without writing a single line of code on the frontend.

As businesses continue to expand across borders, language accessibility becomes a strategic advantage. By embracing low-code translation automation, you're not just simplifying operations â€” you're enhancing the customer experience where it counts the most.

entry.title: Triggering Process in Shared Environments from SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
After this post was written, with the help of the wonderful community, we came up with a different, and in most ways, better solution for this issue. See https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/triggering-process-in-shared-environment-from-sap-build-apps-better/ba-p/14183502.

But what's written in this blog is still valuable, because it will show you how to use the relatively new flow function HTTP Destination Request, which lets you easily and still with a good amount of control call APIs using destinations.

Unfortunately, the Processes flow functions to trigger processes from SAP Build Apps (for now) do not work for shared environments. And since the public environment is deprecated, that means they essentially no longer work at all.  Hopefully this will be modified soon.

In the meantime, here's how to work around that issue.

The Issue

I am not sure but I assume the issue is that when you make an API call to trigger a process in a shared environment, you must send the environment id as a query parameter.

/workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances?environmentId=salesgroup

But the flow functions do not have an input for the environment, so they automatically try to trigger a process in the public (default) environment.

By the way, the identifier for an environment can be found when you open the environment in the Control Tower.

The Workaround

The good news is SAP Build Apps recently added a new flow function called HTTP Destination Request that lets us create a customized HTTP request but using a destination. That is we get the control we get from the HTTP Request flow function but with the ability to connect through a destination.

As a prerequisite you need to have a destination called sap_process_automation_service_user_access to the SAP Build Process Automation service, the same as if you wanted to use the Processes flow functions. This is described in the Processes documentation.

You will need to add the destination properties so that it appears in your SAP Build Apps project:

BuildApps.Enabled = true
BuildApps.ApiType = rest

To add the destination to your project:

  1. Go to the Integrations tab.
  2. Click Add Integration.                                                         
  3.  Click BTP Destinations.
  4. Select the destination.
  5. Click Install Integration.                      

If you go back to the Integrations tab main screen, you'll see the destination. That's all you need to do to add the destination to the project and make it available to your HTTP Destination Request flow function.

To trigger a process deployed to a shared environment, do the following:

  1. Add a button.
  2. In the logic canvas for the button, add an HTTP Destination Request, along with any Alert flow functions to show the result or error
  3. Select the HTTP Destination Request, and set the following in the Properties tab.
    Destinationsap_process_automation_service_user_access
    HTTP MethodPOST
    Request Body Typejson
    Request BodyThis depends on the proper request body for your process. More on this below.
    Path
    /workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances?environmentId=<environment ID>

    Replace the placeholder with the identifier for your environment.

    Response Typetext

       

The flow function has 3 outputs.

  • The first if the call is successful and returns 2XX status code.
  • The second if the call is successfully transmitted and a response is received but returns a 4XX or 5XX status code.
  • The third if the call is unsuccessful and no response is received.  

Request Body

The request body is determined by checking the trigger for the process.

  1. Go to the Control Tower.
  2. Click Environments.
  3. Click your environment.
  4. Click Triggers.
  5. Click View next to the trigger for your process.

You will now see the payload for the API for that trigger. This will be the request body.

Note that you cannot copy from the box with the payload. You will have to use the copy button to copy the entire payload. Note also you can see the URL for the API, including the environmentId parameter you must pass.

The Upshot

The method above is pretty straight-forward and has the advantage of teaching you what is happening behind the scenes and how the SAP Build Process Automation APIs work. But I'll admit you lose the ease of use of the flow functions, and also the ability to create variables from the input and output schema of your processes.

entry.title: Extend a Custom Business Object created with Key User Extensibility using SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
This blog post covers how to setup an extension scenario from SAP S/4HANA Cloud and build Side-by-Side UI Extensions with the help of SAP Build Apps in the Business Technology Platform.

Business scenario:

A Manager wants to define business objects â€œBonus Planâ€ for employees. A Bonus Plan is there to save employee specific rules for bonus entitlement.

Here, with Key User Extensibility, we create a custom Business Object with a data structure, logic for data initialization in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition which should have standard API operations (GET, POST, DELETE). Expose the custom business object as web service for side-by-side UI extension using Low-code No-code capabilities of SAP Build Apps. You will learn how quickly a new UI application can be developed with the no-code capabilities of SAP Build Apps. You will also find out what is the process to setup, develop and deploy a productive extension application.

Note: The maintain Bonus app shown in this blog is for educational purpose only and not meant for productive usage. It is not ensured that the data used in this extension scenario is managed in accordance with applicable legal requirements for all countries and industries and in accordance with the business needs, such as data life cycle requirements.  

Prerequisites:

  1. Subscription to SAP Build Apps on SAP BTP Sub-Account
  2. Your user needs (a) business role(s) with business catalogs Extensibility - Custom Business Objects (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_CBO), Extensibility - Custom Communication Scenarios (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_CCS) and Communication Management (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_COM) (Need to have unrestricted access if you are creating a business role and adding these catalogs).
  3. You have Created Custom Business Objects in SAP S/4HANA Cloud as per the given tutorial.                                                                

Why SAP Build Apps with SAP S/4HANA Cloud?

Create new solutions using the secure, no-code SAP Build Apps with SAP S/4HANA. Build visually and empower users to digitalise their daily work without impacting core processes. Create a personalised, accessible application that securely connects to data from SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

To extend SAP S/4HANA Cloud using SAP Build Apps, you can leverage side-by-side extensibility, which allows you to build extensions that run on SAP BTP and interact with your S/4HANA Cloud system. This approach enables you to create custom UIs, logic, and integrations without directly modifying the core S/4HANA Cloud system. 

 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Letâ€™s start on the SAP S/4HANA Cloud side with the definition of the Custom Business Object and the communication settings.

Custom Business Object

In the Create Custom Business Objects in SAP S/4HANA Cloud tutorial group it is shown how to create a custom business object and generate a UI (user interface) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Expose Custom Business Object as External API

To integrate custom business object from SAP S/4HANA system with External Systems or Services like SAP Build Apps, as administrator you need to create a Communication Arrangement. You create a communication arrangement to enable the communication between your system and SAP Build App in BTP, and how they communicate. Communication Arrangement is formed by combining the below artifacts:

  1. Creating a Custom Communication Scenario
    The setup of the communication (inbound and outbound) between SAP S/4HANA and SAP BTP starts with the definition of a Custom Communication Scenario.
    The Custom Communication Scenario contains the information for both inbound and outbound HTTP-calls.
    • Open the app Custom Communication Scenarios in the Launchpad of the SAP S/4 HANA system and create a new Custom Communication Scenario with the name YY1_BONUSPLAN.

     

    • On the tab Inbound Services, you create an entry for your Custom Business Object: Press Add button to add inbound service â€œYY1_BONUSPLAN_CDSâ€ and click select button. 

     

    • Press Save and Publish to finish the custom communication scenario creation.

     

  2. Creating a Communication System and User

    To enable secure communication between different systems you have to register these systems and define the user which is authorized to use the connection.

    The communication system represents the communication partner within a communication. for inbound communication, this is the external system that calls our custom Bonus plan service.

    Weâ€™ll create one Communication System for all systems that want to use our service as well as the user that theyâ€™ll have to use. If you want to access the custom BONUSPLAN OData service (Inbound) you also need to setup an authentication method. You can use several methods like e.g.., Basic Authentication, Certificate or OAuth.

    In this case we are choosing Basic Authentication for which you need to setup a Communication User. Open the app Maintain Communication Users from the Communication Management group and create there a new user with username, description, and password.

    • Open â€œCommunication Systemsâ€ Application.
    • Start creating a new system by executing the â€œNewâ€ action.
    • Give following data to the new custom communication Systemâ€¦

    Note: you can replace XXX with your system ID.

    Field Label

    Field Value

    System ID

    EXTERNAL_SYSTEMXXX

    System Name

    EXTERNAL_SYSTEMXXX

    Host Name

    EXTERNAL_SYSTEMXXX

    • Scroll down to â€œUser for Inbound Communicationâ€ and start adding one by executing the â€œAddâ€ action.
    • In the Pop Up, use the value help to browse and select the user.

     

    • Choose the user you already created and then click OK. Your user for Inbound Communication is set up. Click on Save.

  3. Creating a Communication Arrangement for Custom Communication Scenario

Finally, a communication arrangement links the solutionâ€™s scenario with the Communication system and its user and exposes the Service to be used.

  • Open â€œCommunication Arrangementsâ€ Application
  • Start creation by executing the â€œNewâ€ action.
  • A pop up opens in that you use the value help for Scenario first where you can select previously created Custom Communication Scenario YY1_BONUSPLAN. This will set the Scenario and default the Arrangement Name, so that you can continue the creation via â€œCreateâ€ button.

  • In the opening Arrangement details click to browse the Communication System
  • Choose the EXTERNAL_SYSTEMXXX you created before.
  • Choosing the system will automatically set the related User as well. Click Save to finish creation
  • Copy the Service URL for the next step. Here you save the inbound service URL for the destination configuration in BTP.

 

 

 

 

 


Build Side-by-Side UI Extensibility with SAP Build Apps

SAP Build Apps enables developers to implement loosely coupled extension applications securely on top of the existing SAP solution they already have. SAP Build Apps provides drag-and-drop capabilities for Citizen developers to build enterprise-grade applications confidently, authenticate and access SAP Business Technology Platform destinations. You can preview your SAP Build Apps project as web preview and can build it to deploy on SAP Build Work Zone or Android/IOS.

Here you will learn how to use SAP Build Apps, create an app that performs all the CRU (Create, Read, Update) operations for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud BONUSPLAN API for managing the Bonus Plan for the employee.

The point of this tutorial is to show you how you would perform all the CRU (Create, Read, Update) operations, and how you would handle some of the complexities of the SAP backend APIs (e.g. strict requirements for the data and handle multiple determination) for the Bonus plan scenario.

You will create an app with 2 pages:

  • Page 1: Display all Bonus plans
  • Page 2: Manage Bonus Plan, which handles Create or Update the bonus plan for employees.

Create destination to SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.   

In the SAP BTP cockpit, as administrator you need to create a destination to enable the communication to the S/4HANA Cloud system. In addition, the destination must be enabled for use in SAP Build Apps.

Procedure:

In the SAP BTP cockpit, navigate to your subaccount.

Choose Connectivity > Destination > Create Destination.

Choose Blank Template and enter the following data and click on Save.

Field

Value

Name

Enter the destination name.

Type

Select HTTP.

Description

Enter a description (SAP Build Apps to ABAP Callback Destination)

URL

Enter the Service URL saved during Communication Arrangement creation. If not saved access the communication arrangement

Proxy Type

Internet

Authentication

Select BasicAuthentication.

User

(Inbound) communication user used in the communication arrangement

Password

Set the password to the secret. Password of the (inbound) communication user used in the communication arrangement.

Additional Properties

Add the following properties:

â€œBuildApps.RequiresCsrfâ€ â†’ true

â€œAppgyverEnabledâ€ â†’ true

â€œHTML5.DynamicDestination â€ â†’ true

Save your entries.

 

 

 

 

 

 


Open SAP Build Apps

Open SAP Build Apps, by going to the SAP BTP cockpit, and under Instances and Subscriptions, click SAP Build Apps.

 

In the lobby of your SAP Build Apps, click Create.

 

Select Application.

 

Select Frontend and followed by this Select Web & Mobile Application and press Next button. Please note that the user needs to have access to the Custom Identity Provider to be able to create a Web & Mobile Application.

For the project name, enter Bonus plan Management and description as â€œExtend a key user extension from S/4HANA Cloud public edition â€œthen click Create.

 

Connect to the REST API from the Custom Business Object on S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

In this step, you will make a connection to the BONUSPLAN API of your SAP S/4HANA Cloud system. You will enable entities: BONUSPLAN (the header for a BONUSPLAN)

  1. Go to the Integrations tab.
  2. Click Add Integration.
  3. Click BTP Destinations, and then select the destination to your SAP S/4HANA Cloud BONUSPLAN API which you have created in â€œCreate destination to SAP S/4HANA Cloud systemâ€ section.
  4. Select Click Install Integration (upper right).
  5. Under Data Entities, scroll down so you can see both YY1_BONUSPLAN and I_Currency. For each, select it and click Enable Data Entity.
  6. You can now select an entity and click Browse Real Data to see live data from SAP S/4HANA Cloud.


  7. Click Save (upper right).



Create page for displaying BONUSPLANs (Homepage)

Now you will create the home page that displays a list of Bonus Plans, for which the user can update the existing Bonus Plan and can create a new Bonus Plan.

  • You will already have a Home Page. Click on it.
  • Click Variables â†’ Data Variables and create a data variable based on YY1_BONUSPLAN.

 

  • Click the User Interface tab to return to the UI canvas. 
  • Add a Title field and a Text field. Set the content for the text component as â€œBonus plan detailsâ€ and add a button with value â€œCreateâ€ value and list item component.


 

 

  • Add a List Item component

 

  • Click the list item, and configure its properties as follows:

Property

Value

Repeat with

data variable YY1_BONUSPLAN1

Primary label

data item in repeat current.EmployeeName

Secondary label

data item in repeat current.EmployeeID

 

Now you can test the application which should display the Bonus list by saving your changes and clicking on Preview to preview the application.

Hopefully you got this far and found success! Congratulations!!!

 

You will define the logic for the list item selection later once we finish next step (Create page for Manage Bonus Plan)

  • With the list item selected, open the logic canvas.
  • Add an Open page flow function, and configure it as follows:

Property

Value

Page

Manage Bonus Plan

Parameters â†’ SAP_UUID

data item in repeat current.SAP_UUID

Parameters â†’ EmployeeName

data item in repeat current. EmployeeName

 


You will define the logic for the Button later once we finish next step (Create page for Manage Bonus Plan)

  • Drag and drop an Open page flow function, and configure it as follows: Make sure that donâ€™t bind any value to the page parameter of Manage Bonus Plan and Page value as â€œManage Bonus Planâ€.


Create page for Manage Bonus Plan

You will create a page for Manage Bonus Plan.

  • Click Add New Page, enter Manage Bonus Plan, and click OK.
  • Navigate to page Manage Bonus Plan
  • Click PAGE PARAMETERS and two parameter such as EmployeeName of type Text and SAP_UUID of type UUID.

 

 

  • Click Data Variables and create a variable for YY1_BONUSPLAN and Data Variable Type as â€œSingle data recordâ€ and bind SAP_UUID value to the page parameter SAP_UUID.

 

 

  • Click View to return to the UI canvas and remove all the default components.
  • Add the following components in this order:
    • Title1
    • Text1
    • Title2
    • Container 1, and inside the container add
      • Input Field
      • CheckBox Field
  • Date field with input1(Date field can be installed from the marketplace if its not available by default)
  • Date field with input2
  • Container 2, and inside the container add          
        • Input Field1
        • Input Field2
  • Container 3, and inside the container add          
        • Input Field1
        • Input Field2
  • Container 4, and inside the container add          
        • Input Field1
        • Input Field2
  • Container 5, and inside the container add
        • Input Field1
        • Dropdown Field2
  • Button
  • Configure the following components:

Component

Title1

Bonus plan

"Bonus plan for " +  IF(NOT(IS_NULLY(params.EmployeeName)), params.EmployeeName, "")

General Information

Add logic to Add/Update Bonus Plan:

  1. Now we will add the logic to the Save button. To achieve this, click on Save button and open its logic canvas.
  2. Add logic flow functions and connect them as in the following:
  3. Configure the flow functions as follows:
  • IF condition (first): Set the condition to the following formula (validates the SAP_UUID field):
    NOT(IS_NULLY(params.SAP_UUID))

Update record: Set the following:

  • Resource name: YY1_BONUSPLAN1
  • Risk ID: page parameter SAP_UUID
  • Record: Set the following formula (allows us to make sure the integer fields receive a number value):

{ ValidityStartDate: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.ValidityStartDate, ValidityEndDate: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.ValidityEndDate,LowBonusAssignmentFactor: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.LowBonusAssignmentFactor,HighBonusAssignmentFactor:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.HighBonusAssignmentFactor,LowBonusPercentage_V: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.LowBonusPercentage_V, HighBonusPercentage_V:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.HighBonusPercentage_V, EmployeeID: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.EmployeeID,  EmployeeName: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.EmployeeName, TargetAmount_V:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.TargetAmount_V, TargetAmount_C:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.TargetAmount_C}

 

Create record: Set the following:

  • Resource name: YY1_BONUSPLAN1
  • Record: Set the following formula:

{ SAP_UUID: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.SAP_UUID, ValidityStartDate: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.ValidityStartDate, ValidityEndDate: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.ValidityEndDate,LowBonusAssignmentFactor: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.LowBonusAssignmentFactor,HighBonusAssignmentFactor:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.HighBonusAssignmentFactor,LowBonusPercentage_V: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.LowBonusPercentage_V, HighBonusPercentage_V:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.HighBonusPercentage_V, EmployeeID: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.EmployeeID,  EmployeeName: data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.EmployeeName, TargetAmount_V:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.TargetAmount_V, TargetAmount_C:data.YY1_BONUSPLAN1.TargetAmount_C}

 

You can set the Toast and Alert flow functions for both Create record and Update record with the appropriate Text message to inform the user about the success or error message during Save.

Now you can now test the application, which is designed to display all available Bonus plans. If you select an existing Bonus Plan, the system will load all relevant field values for the chosen employee, allowing you to update those details. Additionally, you can create a new Bonus Plan by using the Create button and by following the steps mentioned in the section Test app.

Thanks, you have completed SAP Build Apps application development by extending a Custom Business Object successfully! ğŸ˜ŠCongratulations!!!

Test app

  • Open the Preview Portal using the Preview button located in the top-right corner.
  • Go to the Launch tab, then Open Preview Portal, then Web Preview.

 

  • Click Bonus Plan to open the app. You should see the first page with a list of Bonus Plan in the first page and while navigating to the Manage Bonus Plan page handles Create or Update the bonus plan for employees.

For Deploying an app created with SAP Build Apps to HTML5 applications repository on SAP BTP and Integrate an SAP Build Apps application into SAP Build Work Zone, please do refer to this tutorial.

entry.title: Why Clean Core matters - Get some insights into our brand new Extensibility Whitepaper
entry.content:
What is â€œclean coreâ€?

Letâ€™s dive a bit deeper to understand what exactly this means: A SAP Cloud ERP Private has a clean core when it is up to date, documented, unmodified, consistent, efficient, and has custom extensions decoupled from SAP source code.

The clean core concept has multiple dimensions:

  • Business Processes: reduce complexity, because complex processes slow down upgrade cycles
  • Extensibility: decouple extensions from the standard
  • Data: control the data to the latest standards, with respect to volume, cleanliness, accuracy
  • Integration: keep your IT landscape reliable and flexible, using standard APIs and events
  • Operations: keep your operations effective and efficient

In this blog post, we will focus on the method for maintaining this clean core while adapting SAP solutions to meet specific business needs, which is called â€œclean core extensibilityâ€. Flexibility will continue to benefit you in the future if extensions are built and utilized in adherence to clean core principles. For this, SAP provides the private cloud extensibility model for SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Note: The clean core concept only applies to SAP Cloud ERP Private, as the SAP Cloud ERP cannot be customized in its source code, only extended. For the SAP Cloud ERP, SAP provides the public cloud extensibility model for SAP Cloud ERP, which also leverages the SAP BTP.

Now, back to extending SAP Cloud ERP Private.

 

What Is New: The Evolution Of The 3-Tier Model â€“ Introducing The Clean Core Level Concept

SAP is evolving its extensibility guidelines by introducing the Clean Core Level Concept, a new model designed to simplify qualification criteria and provide a more pragmatic approach to managing custom code in SAP Cloud ERP Private, now including rules for classic ABAP. By evolving the previous 3-tier model, this new maturity model categorizes extensions into four distinct levels (A, B, C, and D) based on their architectural integrity, upgrade safety, and alignment with clean core principles.

This allows for a more granular assessment of an extension's quality and upgrade stability, rather than a simple binary "clean" or "unclean" decision. The core recommendation remains a "BTP-first" strategy, aiming for the highest possible level, but the new model acknowledges the realities of complex, grown system landscapes and allows customers to  personalize their clean core journeys. The fundamental principles of Clean Coreâ€”decoupling extensions from the standard SAP code to ensure upgrade stabilityâ€”remain essential.

 

How It Works: The Four Clean Core Levels Explained

According to the Clean Core Level Concept, each extension is evaluated using a standardized methodology that looks at how the extension is built, how well it is decoupled from the core, and how easily it can be upgraded or maintained. Here are the key details of the Clean Core Level Concept:

Overview of Clean Core Levels

The Clean Core Level Concept categorizes extensions into four distinct levels (A, B, C, and D), each representing varying degrees of compliance with Clean Core principles:

  1. Level A : Extend with SAP Build

    • Description: Extensions in this level are fully compliant with Clean Core principles and interact with SAP standard functionality through publicly released interfaces and extension points.
    • Characteristics:
      • Side-by-Side: Developed on SAP BTP, utilizing all options of the SAP Build portfolio including AI-powered pro-code and low-code tools.
      • On-Stack: Built within the SAP SAP Cloud ERP Private system using the ABAP Cloud development model with released APIs.
    • Benefits: Maximum upgrade stability and alignment with SAP's clean core vision.

  2. Level B : Leverage Classic APIs

    • Description: Extensions at this level can access "classic APIs" from SAP, in addition to meeting Level A criteria.
    • Characteristics:
      • These APIs are well-defined, documented, and generally upgrade-stable but do not come with formal stability contracts.
      • Classic technologies and frameworks can be used, which have a long-standing history of reliable use.
    • Benefits: Broader scope for process enhancements compared to Level A while maintaining a degree of upgrade stability.

  3. Level C : Access Internal Objects

    • Description: Extensions classified as Level C can access internal SAP objects that are not officially released or supported.
    • Characteristics:
      • These objects may lack documentation and long-term stability guarantees.
      • A changelog for SAP objects is provided to help customers assess upgrade risks proactively.
    • Benefits: Offers flexibility for legacy scenarios but poses notable risks regarding future upgrade stability.

  4. Level D : Not Recommended Extensions

    • Description: Extensions in this category use objects or techniques that SAP has explicitly marked as "not recommended."
    • Characteristics:
      • Includes modifications to SAP standard code, implicit enhancements, and direct write access to SAP tables.
      • Represents the highest risk and the most significant technical debt.
    • Consequences: These extensions threaten system stability and upgradeability and should be prioritized for immediate remediation.

Importance of the Level Concept

  • Granular Assessment: The level concept allows for a more nuanced evaluation of extensions compared to a binary "clean" or "unclean" decision. This granularity helps organizations understand the specific risks associated with their custom code.
  • Guidance for Development: By categorizing extensions into levels, developers can make informed decisions about which technologies and practices to adopt, aiming for the highest possible level of compliance.
  • Facilitating Modernization: The framework supports organizations in managing their existing codebases effectively, helping them prioritize remediation of the highest-risk extensions (Level D) while promoting the adoption of clean, upgrade-stable practices.

Conclusion

The Clean Core Level Concept is essential for organizations leveraging SAP Cloud ERP Private, offering a clear framework to assess and categorize custom extensions. By distinguishing between Levels A, B, C, and D, it enables businesses to make informed development decisions, prioritize remediation of high-risk extensions, and ensure compliance with Clean Core principles. This structured approach not only helps manage technical debt but also simplifies upgrades and enhances overall system integrity, paving the way for sustained agility and innovation. Embracing this framework is key to maintaining a robust and future-ready ERP landscape.

Leverage SAP Build for creating extensions

The go-to place following SAP-recommended best practices to create extensions optimized for SAP software development is SAP Build. It includes

  • powerful low-code, pro-code (ABAP, Java, JavaScript), and generative AI capabilities
  • enhanced interoperability with SAP Cloud ERP Private

to empower developers and business experts to create extensions for SAP software with greater efficiency. It allows you to accelerate ERP modernization, foster innovation, and automate processes â€“ all within a single comprehensive suite of solutions.

 

Accelerate extension of SAP S/4HANA with AI capabilities enabled by Joule

New levels of Cloud ERP efficiency can be unlocked with the latest AI capabilities enabled by Joule in SAP Build. Joule is SAPâ€™s AI copilot offering conversational interactions in the respective business context. Uniquely trained on SAP data and processes, it helps developers write code and design workflows for SAP S/4HANA across ABAP, Java, JavaScript, and low-code tools. As an integral part of SAP Build, Joule is the copilot for SAP development and makes developers more efficient with their development tasks for SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Joule generates high-quality code and code explanations aligned with SAPâ€™s programming models, thereby reducing development time for both new and experienced developers and accelerating migration to cloud ERP with a clean core.

AI capabilities enabled by Joule can also be used to extend ERP through low-code application development. Joule assists with process automation, expediting the creation of workflows for SAP Cloud ERP Private and guiding workflow approvers with automated recommendations.

How to Get Started?

First and foremost, read our white paper on Clean core extensibility for SAP Cloud ERP Private . The last chapter of the document details the six-step path to a clean core and links to many useful resources to deep dive:

  1. Start with the clean core concept and definition
  2. Apply the concept and create your specific clean core strategy
  3. Analyze existing custom code (brownfield only)
  4. Adopt extension guidelines and methodologies
  5. Establish clean core governance and operations
  6. Build extensions

In addition, depending of the line of business youâ€™re involved in, read our eBook presenting how to Extend SAP S/4HANA with SAP Build with use cases by LoB, including Finance, Supply chain, Sales and service, Operations and IT.

And regarding the use of SAP Build for extending your ERP, I recommend watching the replay of our SAP Build Live online event on Clean Core extensibility with SAP Build held on October 23, where our partner LeverX shared insights from a real customer use case.

For ABAP-based extensibility for clean core see the ABAP Extensibility Guide.

Finally, we have a learning journey for you:

Managing Clean Core for SAP Cloud ERP Private will present you how to evaluate and apply clean core principles to ERP so that they can maximize business process agility, reduce adaptation efforts, and accelerate innovation. It is for beginners, takes 2 hours and is free.

Now you're ready to begin your fruitful journey to achieve Clean Core!

entry.title: SAP BTP Hackathon at SAPHILA 2025: Celebrating the Winners and Innovation in Action
entry.content:
A few months ago, we shared our excitement about the launch of the first-ever SAP BTP Hackathon in Africa in joined collaboration of AFSUG and SAP, highlighting the unique opportunity it offered for AFSUG members to bring their creativity and problem-solving skills to the forefront of the SAP community. Now, with the event behind us, itâ€™s time to reflect on what unfolded and celebrate the teams and ideas that made this inaugural Hackathon truly special.

From Ideation to Demo Jam: A Journey of Collaboration

As outlined in the previous blog, the hackathon was more than just a competition, it was a journey. Eighteen teams, representing a broad cross-section of AFSUG members, embarked on an eight-week sprint, supported by SAP BTP experts and coaches. The focus was on building real-world solutions using SAP BTP components like SAP Build, SAP HANA Cloud, SAP Integration Suite and ABAP Cloud amongst other SAP BTP based Services & Solutions.

After intensive enablement and development sessions, three teams emerged as finalists and were invited to present their solutions live at SAPHILA 2025â€™s Demo Jam. The energy in the room was palpable as each team showcased how SAP BTP could be harnessed to solve pressing business challenges.

And the Winner Isâ€¦ PwC South Africa!

In a closely contested finale, the SAPHILA audience voted PwC South Africa as the overall winner for their AI-driven legal services platform â€œLegal Easeâ€. This solution stood out for its innovative use of AI to simplify legal document processing and understanding, a pain point for many businesses and consumers alike. â€œLegal Easeâ€ enables users to scan and summarize complex contracts, ask questions in natural language, and receive clear, actionable insights. The platform even supports translation into local languages and integrates with knowledge bases for related services.

What impressed both the jury and the audience was not just the technical sophistication, but the clear business value: â€œLegal Easeâ€ addresses real frustrations around contract transparency, billing and accessibility, with the potential to transform how legal services are delivered in Africa and beyond.

Honouring the Finalists: Debswana Diamond Company and Bell Equipment

Letâ€™s not forget the other two finalists, who also delivered outstanding solutions:

  • Debswana Diamond Company tackled overtime management with an AI-powered assistant that streamlines scheduling, reduces costs and supports employee well-being.
  • Bell Equipment automated shipment tracking and document processing, helping to prevent stock shortages and improve logistics efficiency.

Both teams demonstrated the breadth of innovation possible with SAP BTP and set a high bar for future Hackathons.

Reflections and Whatâ€™s Next

The Hackathonâ€™s main objective was to foster deep collaboration between SAP and its customers, giving local teams a hands-on opportunity to explore and build with SAP BTP. The quality and diversity of solutions, especially the creative use of AI and automation, highlight the immense potential within the African SAP community.

Amanda Gibbs, CEO of AFSUG, summed it up perfectly:

â€œIt is inspiring to witness what can be achieved in just eight weeks using SAP BTP;

weâ€™ve seen incredible progress and innovation.â€

Join the Conversation

Congratulations again to all teams who participated and especially to PwC South Africa for their winning solution! If you were inspired by the SAP BTP Hackathon or have thoughts on how SAP BTP can drive innovation in your organization, Iâ€™d love to hear from you in the comments.

And if you missed out this year, keep an eye out for future SAP BTP Hackathons - this is just the beginning!

entry.title: AIâ€‘Powered Selfâ€‘Service Portal with SAP Build Apps and SAP Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
Abstract

In this demo, we showcase an intelligent selfâ€‘service portal built with SAP Build Apps, seamlessly integrated with SAP Service Cloud V2 and SAP AI Core. End users submit a service request by uploading an image . The image is analyzed in AI Core to detect key objects or issues; the findings are then merged into the case description so agents start with rich context. We also run sentiment analysis on the userâ€™s text, helping autoâ€‘prioritize and categorize the case. The result is an endâ€‘toâ€‘end, lowâ€‘code + AI workflow that reduces manual effort, improves accuracy, and accelerates resolution time.

Use Case: Broken Home Appliance Service Request

Scenario:
A customerâ€™s washing machine stops working and makes unusual noise. Instead of calling customer support, they log into the self-service portal built on SAP Build Apps.

What youâ€™ll build

A responsive selfâ€‘service portal where customers can:

  • Log in, fill a lightweight form, and upload a photo (e.g., broken product/utility issue).
  • See realâ€‘time AI insights (objects detected; suspected issue) before submitting.
  • Submit a Service Request (Case) to Service Cloud V2, with AI context appended to the description and sentiment tag autoâ€‘set.

Agents in Service Cloud V2 will see a richer ticket with:

  • Customer text + image URL/attachment.
  • AI object/issue summary and confidence scores.
  • Sentiment label (Positive/Neutral/Negative) for quick triage.

Solution Overview

The solution leverages three modern SAP technologies:

  • SAP Build Apps: Low-code environment for building web/mobile self-service portals.
  • SAP BTP Destination: Secure connection layer to backend SAP services.
  • SAP Service Cloud V2: Manages and tracks customer service cases.
  • SAP AI Core: Automates image analysis and sentiment analysis to enhance ticket information

The workflow (as visualized below) demonstrates how these layers interact:

  • End-to-End Ticket Automation: Instantly raise service requests by uploading an image.
  • AI-Powered Image Analysis: Automatic detection of objects or issues in uploaded images via SAP AI Core.
  • Auto-Enriched Ticket Descriptions: AI writes relevant context and details.
  • Sentiment Analysis: Analyzes customer descriptions for emotion and urgency for better case triaging.

Reference architecture

 

Prerequisites

Before starting, ensure you have the following in place:

SAP BTP Account with access to:

  • SAP Build Apps service
  • SAP AI Core service
  • SAP Service Cloud V2 tenant

Service Keys and Destinations:

  • Properly configured SAP BTP Destination for Service Cloud V2 and SAP AI Core

AI Models Deployed:

  • Object Detection model ( in SAP AI Core)
  • Sentiment Analysis model
  • Basic understanding of SAP BTP, Destinations, and Service Cloud concepts

Stepâ€‘byâ€‘step build guide

1.Prepare Your AI Services in SAP AI Core

  • Deploy or onboard your image recognition and sentiment analysis models to SAP AI Core.
  • Expose these models through RESTful endpoints.

2. Configure Destinations in SAP BTP Cockpit

Create destinations for:

  • SAP Service Cloud V2 API
  • SAP AI Core inference endpoints
  • Set appropriate authentication methods (OAuth2, Basic, etc.).

3.Build the Self-Service Portal with SAP Build Apps

  • Use SAP Build Appsâ€™ drag-and-drop interface to design a user-friendly portal.
  • Add functionality for:
    • User authentication
    • Image upload
    • Input fields for additional ticket information
  • Configure data resources to connect to SAP Service Cloud V2 and SAP AI Core via the BTP destinations.

Build the portal in SAP Build Apps

Step 1: Create an SAP Build Apps portal tailored to your requirements.

Step 2: Implement logic to process the uploaded image using SAP AI Core. Extract the description from the image and perform sentiment analysis on the extracted text. Based on the description and sentiment, automatically update the subject line and categorize the case accordingly.

Step 3: Invoke the Service Cloud V2 API to create a case along with the attachment.

Video

 

Summary

This approach shows how you can build a pure destinationâ€‘driven integration between Build Apps, AI Core, and Service Cloud V2. By leveraging SAP BTP Destinations, you eliminate the need for custom middleware, keep the architecture lightweight, and still enable AIâ€‘powered case creation with images, sentiment, and prioritization.
