entry.title: Triggering Process in Shared Environment from SAP Build Apps - Better Solution ğŸ˜¸
entry.content:
In my previous blog post Triggering Process in Shared Environments from SAP Build Apps,  I showed you how to trigger from SAP Build Apps a process that was deployed to a shared environment  -- using HTTP Destination Request instead of Processes flow functions.

Though I thought it was pretty easy -- and I liked it because I could control the API call and see what was going on under the hood -- it still required me to know the APIs as well as to give up on some of the cool SAP Build Apps capabilities that come with the Processes flow functions (like automatic generation of schemas from inputs/outputs of a process).

Thanks to @KuroKen, I discovered a better way, who commented on my original post.

At first I struggled to get the solution to work, even though I was assured it worked. But as usual, the struggling was good and revealed all kinds of additional nuances about the system (see Issues below). After 2 weeks of study, here's my explanation of this solution.

The Problem (reminder)

SAP Build Apps has a wonderful set of flow functions that makes it easy to trigger processes (and run other SAP Build Process Automation APIs). 

But the problem is that they were developed before SAP Build environments was a big thing, and certainly before the Public environment was deprecated. The API to trigger a process in a shared environment requires a query parameter specifying the environment, but the flow functions do not include this parameter and therefore the flow function can only trigger Public processes, which as we said are deprecated.

ğŸ™€

The Solution

Well, it is pretty simple -- don't require the query parameter.

But how?

When creating the SAP Build Process Automation instance in the SAP BTP cockpit, you can add a small configuration  that will assign that instance to a specific shared environment so you will not have to pass the environment name when you call the API.

To set up SAP Build Process Automation, you need to create an instance of the service. In the cockpit click Create.

You select SAP Build Process Automation, and select the standard instance plan. 

Instead of clicking Create, click Next so you can add a configuration to specify a shared environment to connect to this instance. In the dialog, you enter an environment ID and an API key with rights to trigger processes and more.

The following is the dialog where you post your configuration:

The following is an example of the JSON to set (you need to replace with your own environment ID and API key):

{
    "environmentId": "salesgroup",
    "apiKey": "fPdjgABCD-wZUckjh-c6e2wFyU3SgL"
}

 If you already have an instance, you can run Update and then supply the JSON.

Some of this process is described here: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/update-service-instance

Environment ID

The environment ID can be found when you go to Control Tower and open your environment, under Identifier.

API Key

Within the environment, you can go to the API Keys tab and create a new API key.

For the key you must give it enough scope for triggering processes, specifically the environment_read, trigger_read and trigger_execute scopes.

 

How You Trigger Process from SAP Build Apps

Now that we have overcome the problem with shared environments, here's a quick review of how to trigger a process from SAP Build Apps.

  1. Publish your deployed process project.
  2.  In SAP Build Apps, go to Integrations > Add Integration > Library, and select the process you want to expose from within the deployed project (which should appear since the project was published). Click Enable Process. 
  3. In the logic canvas (perhaps in response to a button), drag in a Processes > Trigger Process flow function. 
  4. In the flow function, specify the process to trigger and the inputs for the process.

 

Issues

The main issue was that I was using a destination with OAuth2JWTBearer (user authentication). The above works currently only for OAuth2ClientCredentials. So when @KuroKen explained his solution, I didn't understand because it didn't work for me, and he must of thought I was incompetent or crazy.

I contacted development and they confirmed that I was not crazy, that in fact there was a bug -- the client credentials and user token authentication flows used different flows and the one for user tokens had a bug. My understanding is that that bug was fixed and is awaiting deployment. As always,, no guarantees

Potential pitfall

This solution works like a charm, and restores all the great capabilities of SAP Build Apps flow functions. And as long as long as there are only a few environments, it should work pretty well.

But let's say I have 3 environments, and I create 3 instances of SAP Build Process Automation, each will require its own destination to define the connection from SAP Build Apps. But SAP Build Apps assumes the name of the destination is sap_process_automation_service_user_access. So in a  case where I want to trigger processes in different environments from my app, I think I would have a problem -- though I do not know how common a use case that would be.

I am told that there is no cost or performance issue for creating multiple instances, so that is good.

I assume that I can override the configuration by sending the query parameter for another environment, but I have not tested this.

Hope this helps,

ğŸ˜¸

entry.title: SAP Databricks: Create inferences for application integration with SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
Part 1 â€“ SQL analytics with SAP Data Products
Part 2 â€“ Build and deploy Mosaic AI and Agent Tools
Part 3 â€“ How to use AutoML to forecast sales data
Part 4 â€“ Connect SAP Data Products with non-SAP data from AWS S3
Part 5 â€“ End-to-end integration: SAP Databricks, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Analytics Cloud
Part 6 â€“ Create inferences for application integration with SAP Build 
Part 7 â€“ SAP Databricks in SAP Business Data Cloud - A Typical Machine Learning Workflow

 

Create inferences for application integration with SAP Build Apps

In the earlier parts of the series, we explored the capabilities of SAP Databricks - from running SQL analytics and leveraging AutoML, to building end-to-end data integration with SAC. Now, we're taking things a step further.

In this post, the focus shifts from model development to real-world application - specifically, how to extend trained and deployed ML models into interactive, user-facing applications.

Weâ€™ll walk through how to:

  • Leverage data products from Unity Catalog and enhance them using notebooks
  • Serve a trained ML model for real-time inference
  • Use SAP Build Apps (low-code/no-code) to rapidly build a front-end interface that interacts with the model for inference

By integrating SAP Databricks with SAP Build Apps, we extend the powerful capabilities of notebooks into the creation of intelligent applications, enabling machine learning experiences to directly benefit end users. With SAP Build Apps, it's quick and easy to prototype and bring these ML-powered experiences to life, even without deep frontend development expertise.

 

1. Data Preparation and Feature Engineering

The goal is to train a machine learning model to predict sales order lead times based on inputs such as product, order date, and quantity. In my environment, I accessed the sales order data products from the SAP Databricks Unity Catalog, which was delta-shared from S/4 HANA.

The data was cleaned and preprocessed by addressing missing or inconsistent values, particularly focusing on improving the accuracy of the delivery dates. Relevant features were also added to enhance the dataset, including order lead time, day of the week, and month.

 

Once the data is cleaned up, I saved this back into the Unity Catalog as a delta table. Saving the cleaned and feature engineered table allows you to manage and share datasets across your teams with access control. By storing the processed table here, I could easily access it for model training, and downstream tasks while maintaining version control and consistency.

 

2. Model Training

I used XGBoost to train a model to predict the lead time based on the features. You can use any ML models that suits your use case or take a look at how to run AutoML experiments in Part 3 (link).

 

3. Mosaic AI Model Serving

Mosaic AI Model Serving offers a unified platform to deploy, manage, and run AI/ML models for both real-time and batch predictions. Once deployed, each model is exposed as a REST API that can be easily integrated into web or client applications.

The model being deployed here is a Custom Model, built using Python and trained with standard machine learning libraries or custom code. It is packaged in the MLflow format and can be registered in the SAP Databricks workspace model registry as a Python pyfunc model.

Package your model into a Python class that can be called easily:

# Model wrapper class for XGBoost regression to predict LeadTime
import mlflow.pyfunc
import pandas as pd
from mlflow.models.signature import ModelSignature
from mlflow.types import Schema, ColSpec


class LeadTimeModel(mlflow.pyfunc.PythonModel):
    def __init__(self, model_pipeline):
        self.model_pipeline = model_pipeline

    def predict(self, context, model_input):
        # Convert input to pandas DataFrame regardless of input type
        if isinstance(model_input, pd.DataFrame):
            input_df = model_input
        elif isinstance(model_input, dict):
            input_df = pd.DataFrame([model_input])
        else:
            input_df = pd.DataFrame(model_input)
        predictions = self.model_pipeline.predict(input_df)
        return pd.DataFrame({'predicted_lead_time': predictions})

# Define input and output schema
input_feature_names = [
    "SalesOrderDayOfWeek",
    "SalesOrderDay",
    "SalesOrderMonth",
    "SalesOrderItemText",
    "OrderQuantity"
]
input_schema = Schema([
    ColSpec("string", "SalesOrderDayOfWeek"),
    ColSpec("long", "SalesOrderDay"),
    ColSpec("long", "SalesOrderMonth"),
    ColSpec("string", "SalesOrderItemText"),
    ColSpec("long", "OrderQuantity")
])
output_schema = Schema([ColSpec("long", "predicted_lead_time")])
signature = ModelSignature(inputs=input_schema, outputs=output_schema)

input_example = pd.DataFrame([{
    "SalesOrderDayOfWeek": "Monday",
    "SalesOrderDay": 13,
    "SalesOrderMonth": 8,
    "SalesOrderItemText": "Y120 Bike",
    "OrderQuantity": 5
}])

with mlflow.start_run():
    mlflow.pyfunc.log_model(
        "lead-time-pred", 
        python_model=LeadTimeModel(model_pipeline), 
        input_example=input_example, 
        signature=signature, 
        registered_model_name="lead-time-prediction"
    )

Code run below: 

â€ƒ

Track and manage your model lifecycle in the Unity Catalog:

 

 

Create a model serving endpoint

Since the model is registered, you could fill in the endpoint name, select the trained model, and compute type. Take note that the endpoint name cannot be changed after creation. 

 

Test the deployed model endpoint by clicking the 'Use' button located at the top-right corner to view the screen below: 

With model serving, users can instantly run inferences on the trained ML models. For example, given a sales order with fields like product and quantity, the model can predict lead time on the spot. This capability allows product and operations teams to call the service live within their workflows. You can easily test the functionality first through a simple query endpoint from the model serving endpoint.

For testing purposes, you can create a personal access token: link

For production use, you can authenticate SAP Databricks with OAuth.

More details on model serving: link 

 

4. Accelerate Development Using SAP Build Apps

SAP Build Apps enables quick app development with a low-code platform, allowing you to create custom applications. In this section, we'll demonstrate how we can rapidly prototype a user interface to interact with the deployed model.

For testing purpose, I used the PAT (Personal Access Token).

In the Integration tab, specify the relative path and query for the model, then run tests on the API to check your connection.

 

Build the UI with the drag and drop interface.

 

A simple demo below shows the prototype built on SAP Build Apps to perform inference on the model served from SAP Databricks.

 

Conclusion

The application design may vary depending on its complexity and the steps required to make it production-ready. To manage connections and handle additional logic, a backend would be needed. However, this demonstrates how to enhance a data product, serving the ML model on SAP Databricks for inference and connecting it to SAP Build Apps via API, providing a foundation to extend and build your own intelligent applications.

entry.title: â€œBusiness Excellence with SAPâ€™s New Clean Core Extensibility Levels: Why, What and Howâ€
entry.content:
1. Introduction:

SAP provides pre-delivered content to run your business. A Clean Core approach means keeping Cloud ERP systems up-to-date, free from unnecessary customizations, and aligned with industry best practices. This gives the benefits of driving innovation-readiness, ensuring seamless future upgrades and reducing technical debt.

1.1 Key guiding principles of a Clean Core

There are five essential guiding principles that contribute to an efficient and sustainable Cloud ERP system:

  1. Processes â€“ Streamlining end-to-end (E2E) business workflows for efficiency.
  2. Integration â€“ Ensuring seamless communication between extensions and core enterprise solutions.
  3. Extensibility â€“ Extending standard software functionality to meet unique organizational needs.
  4. Data â€“ Managing configuration, master, and transactional data effectively.
  5. Operations â€“ Managing infrastructure, upgrades, system monitoring, and maintenance.

In this article, we will focus on the â€œExtensibilityâ€ guiding principle.

To support business differentiation while maintaining a Clean Core, organizations can adopt various extensibility models.  A clean core strategy doesn't mean to exclude extensibility entirely, the crucial part is understanding the appropriate way to implement the extensions.  You can create extensions using SAP Build via â€œSide-by-sideâ€ extensibility (loosely coupled) on BTP (including AI-enhanced pro-code and low-code tools) or through â€œS/4 HANA On-stackâ€ extensibility (tightly coupled).

2. WHY New Clean Core Extensibility Levels:

SAP has refined its clean core model, evolving from the former three-tier structure to a more detailed four-level concept (A, B, C, and D). Instead of a simple â€œclean vs. not cleanâ€ classification. These levels show how closely your custom extensions align with clean core principles.

This evolution provides greater clarity for extension decisions and simplifies qualification criteria, giving organizations a more practical way to balance innovation with long-term sustainability. Itâ€™s about making smarter, future-proof extensibility choices while ensuring business differentiation doesnâ€™t come at the cost of technical debt.

Hereâ€™s what it means in practice:

  1. Smarter, future-proof choices â€“ Enable meaningful business differentiation without slowing down with legacy overhead.
  2. Clean, scalable extensions â€“ Build on SAP BTP, ABAP Cloud, and SAP Buildâ€”all supported by Joule, SAPâ€™s AI copilot.
  3. Progress you can measure â€“ Monitor and track clean core adoption with tools like the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard and ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC). The dashboards will be updated and reflect the new levels.

3. WHAT are the new clean core extensibility Levels:

Before exploring the new clean core extensibility levels are, it is important to understand what an API isâ€”because most of these levels are closely tied to APIs.

  • An API (Application Programming Interface) is essentially a defined set of rules, protocols, and interfaces that allows one software application to communicate with another.
  • In simple terms, an API acts like a bridge. It lets developers access specific functions, data, or services of a system without needing to dive into, or modify, the underlying code.

There are four extensibility levels from the cleanest form of extensions to not clean extensions.

Level A â€“ The cleanest form of custom extensions. These are built either directly on-stack with the ABAP Cloud development model or side-by-side on SAP BTP using SAP Build, whether through ABAP Cloud, CAP, or low-code/no-code tools. Represents highest standard in SAP extensibility, offering future-ready solutions with maximum upgrade stability by utilizing released APIâ€™s and extension points.

Level B â€“Extensions that follow SAPâ€™s best practices for classic ABAP development and use only officially provided SAP APIs and frameworks. These extensions can be used only if the requirements cannot be fulfilled by set of released APIs (Level A). These include wide range of legacy APIs, user exits, BadIs and established frameworks like SAP GUI and ABAP list viewer grid.

Level C â€“ Extensions at Level C involve the use of SAP internal objects that are not classified or intended for customer use. These objects are neither officially released, recommended, nor cloud-ready, and they fall outside SAPâ€™s formal support scope. However, with the introduction of the new changelog for SAP objects (currently in work and will become later available), customers can proactively analyze and plan for potential upgrade impacts when Level C objects are affected by incompatible changes. For this reason, Level C extensions are considered conditionally clean.

Level D â€“ Classified as not clean core. This level includes extensions that donâ€™t follow SAPâ€™s guidelines, such as system modifications, reliance on non-recommended SAP objects, or unsupported techniques like implicit enhancements.

Below table explains the differences in each level for comparison.

For detailed guidance on frameworks, technologies and development patterns in the context of clean core extensibility, please refer to SAP Note: 3578329.

4. HOW to find SAP extensibility objects classification by levels:

The â€œSAP Business Accelerator Hubâ€ and â€œCloudification Repository (API Viewer)â€ are the central tools to classify objects by clean core level. It shows which objects are:

  • Released APIs (Level A)
  • Classic APIs (Level B)
  • No APIs (Level D)
  • Internal Objects (Level C â€“ default when not classified as A, B and D)

The SAP API Business Hub is SAPâ€™s central catalog of APIs, integration content, and business services. All the APIs are classified as Level A. Remote APIs are for consumption in BTP and local APIs are for consumption in â€œOn-stack extensibilityâ€.

The Cloudification Repository Viewer is an interactive tool designed to help developers explore API details for â€œSAP S/4HANA Cloud Publicâ€ and â€œSAP S/4HANA Private Editionâ€ for on-stack extensions.

Links:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (Doesnâ€™t include Classic APIs)
  • SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition (Classic APIâ€™s)

In this article, I will be demonstrating the usage of â€œS/4 HANA Cloud Private Editionâ€.

4.1 Extension Level A

The cleanest form of custom extensions. These are built either directly on-stack with the ABAP Cloud development model or side-by-side on SAP BTP using SAP Build, whether through ABAP Cloud, CAP, or low-code/no-code tools. You can find the released APIâ€™s at SAP Business Accelerator Hub. If you are a developer, you can find the released APIâ€™s directly in the IDE (Integrated Development Environment).

 Alternatively, for â€œSAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition" you can follow the below steps.

Detailed Steps:

1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud ERP Private  (Doesnâ€™t include Classic APIs)
2. Click â€œShow Filter Barâ€

3. Choose â€œReleasedâ€ under State drop down.

4. You have different options to filter results based on â€œObject typeâ€, â€œSoftware Componentâ€ and â€œApplication Componentâ€

5. You can also search for objects (Example of search results for â€œpurchase_orderâ€)

4.2 Extension Level B â€“ Classics APIs:

Extensions that follow SAPâ€™s best practices for classic ABAP development and use only officially provided SAP APIs and frameworks. These extensions can be used only if the requirements cannot be fulfilled by set of released APIs (Level A). These include wide range of legacy APIs, user exits, BadIs and established frameworks like SAP GUI and ABAP list viewer grid.

Detailed Steps on finding the Classic APIâ€™s:

  1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition (Classic APIâ€™s)
  2. Click â€œShow Filter Barâ€

3. Choose â€œClassic APIâ€ in the state 

4. You can choose filter criteria as needed

5. You can also search for objects (Example of search results for â€œsalesâ€)

4.3 Extension Level C â€“ Conditionally Clean

Extensions at Level C involve the use of SAP internal objects that are not classified or intended for customer use. These objects are neither officially released, recommended, nor cloud-ready, and they fall outside SAPâ€™s formal support scope. However, with the introduction of the new changelog for SAP objects (currently in work and will become later available), customers can proactively analyze and plan for potential upgrade impacts when Level C objects are affected by incompatible changes. For this reason, Level C extensions are considered conditionally clean.

  • You can find objects in Level A (Released APIs), Level B (Classical APIs) and Level D (No APIs).

Level C refers to all internal SAP objects that are neither â€œReleased APIs,â€ â€œClassical APIs,â€ nor â€œAPIsâ€ at all. Since they are internal objects, no official list exists.

4.4 Extension Level D â€“ Not Clean Core

Extensions at level D are classified as not clean core. These includes extensions that doesnâ€™t follow SAPâ€™s guidelines, such as system modifications, reliance on non-recommended SAP objects, or unsupported techniques like implicit enhancements.

Detailed Steps on finding objects which are â€œNot APIsâ€ classified as â€œNo APIsâ€

  1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition (Classic APIâ€™s)
  2. Click â€œShow Filter Bar

3. Choose â€œNo APIâ€ in State

4. Results with â€œNo APIsâ€ are displayed

5. Successor information is available for some of the objects.

5. Summary:
With this evolved model, SAP is giving organizations a smarter playbook for extension decisions. By aligning with clean core principles on a clear scale (Levels A, B, C and D), businesses can innovate faster, keep their systems future-ready, and reduce technical debtâ€”while still getting the flexibility they need today.

6. References:

entry.title: ğŸŸ¡ Fun for Week 1: The Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt ğŸ”¨ğŸª™
entry.content:
Welcome to the Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt, a chase around important SAP developer-related tools/sites, a challenge to construct a secret phrase, and a chance to win 1000s of points toward the Devtoberfest grand prize.

The hunt officially starts Sept. 25, with the release of the first clue during that day's SAP Developer News, and you have until the end of Devtoberfest, Oct. 24, to complete it.

To get all the clues make sure to SUBSCRIBE TO THIS POST!!

Learn more about the  entire Devtoberfest event in @KevinR's post Devtoberfest 2025 Welcome!.

 

What you need to find

We have hidden a special phrase, which you need to figure out using the clues from several missions, described in the next section. Along your journey you will do the following:

  1. Visit about 10 different locations related to SAP developers, mostly web sites that are designed to help you in your daily SAP development.
  2. At each location, you will discover a set of hexadecimal digits.
  3. Concatenate the digits together (in the order of the missions) to get one, 37-digit hexadecimal number.
  4. Multiply that hexadecimal number by another secret number, for which we will give a clue.
  5. Take the resulting 38-digit hexadecimal product, and convert it into the secret phrase, using each pair of digits as values for ASCII characters.
  6. Enter the phrase, exactly (case-sensitive, no extra spaces), into the Scavenger Hunt tutorial.â€Œ

Not until the SAP Developer News of Oct. 16 will you have all the pieces to be able to complete the phrase. 

Example Hunt

As an example of what you will have to do, here's a short sample hunt (just a warm-up, no points will be earned). Each mission is independent of the other.

MissionNo. DigitsSAP Web PropertyInstructions
17

SAP Developers YouTube Channel

Go to our SAP Developer YouTube channel. 

Open @Rekha_DR's video "SAP Build Process Automation (Part 1): Build your very first process". Watch it and find the secret 7-digit hexadecimal number in one of the info cards.

You can also see the hex digits in the description.

26SAP Community

Inside this blog post, use the Developer Tools on your browser to inspect the words "SAP Community" in the cell immediately to the left (in this very table) and find the 6-digit RGB ASCII code for the color of the text. 

3None (directly) 

Concatenate the 2 sets of hexadecimal digits (13 in all), in order, and multiply the resulting hexadecimal number by the number of original SAP founders (you can easily find the number on the SAP Wikipedia page).

Convert the resulting hexadecimal number into a phrase, converting each pair of digits into a character using ASCII codes.

ğŸ‘‰In this blog post, post a comment/picture about the phrase -- but NOT the phrase itself  (like your experiences with or opinion about the phrase, or a picture of something belonging to you that reminds you of the phrase). You won't get any points, but it will be fun and you will be ready for the real scavenger hunt. If you have any trouble with this example hunt, post in the comments.

REMINDER: The above is just an example of how the real scavenger hunt will work. The real scavenger hunt instructions will be described in the rest of this blog post, as clues become available.

 

The (real) hunt

Below are the instructions for finding the hexadecimal digits for the actual scavenger hunt. We will release clues as follows:

  • In the SAP Developer News of Sept. 25, Oct. 2, Oct. 9, and Oct. 16.
  • In this blog each Monday during the first 3 weeks of Devtoberfest.

ğŸ‘‰To be notified when a new clue is released, SUBSCRIBE TO THIS POST!!

â€Œ When you find the secret phase, just enter it into this Devtoberfest tutorial.

To guide you, we have created a second tutorial -- you do not have to use it, nor do you get any points from it. But you can enter the 1 to 6 digits from each mission to check if you received the correct digits for that mission.

Here are your missions 

 

MissionNo.
Digits		SAP Web PropertyInstructions
12

SAP Developer News

The Developer News comes out each Thursday with the latest about ABAP, CAP, BTP, SAP Build, UI5, Fiori, AI, and all your favorite SAP developer topics. All delivered by some of your favorite Developer Advocates, like DJ, Shilpa Shankar, Thomas Jung, Antonio Maradiaga, Nora von Thenen and the rest of the gang.

Most episodes about 5 minutes. Also available as a Podcast.

Watch the Developer News of Sept. 25 for this mission's clue 
26

Developer Forums in SAP Community

Check the just-released new developer forums area of the SAP Community, where you can find info about your specific area of developer interest and ask fellow community members your questions. Use it to find other community members with the same skills as you.

Go to the new Developers area and the forums by going to the top-level menu of the SAP Community and then navigating to Developers > All Developer Forums.

Check out the different topics and sub-areas (and feel free to ask any question you have about your work, or to answer someone else's).

Now search for a forum post about "Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt" for the next hex digits in the contest -- the post is in the forum topic that I cover as a Developer Advocate and which is the focus on Tuesday's of Devtoberfest. 

34

SAP Business Accelerator Hub

The SAP Business Accelerator Hub contains API reference guides, SAP Build templates, BAdIs for extensions, CDS data models, event descriptions and other artifact documentation that can help you with your development.

Explore the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, to check out all the artifacts available in SAP products for building your extensions.

42

sap-samples org in GitHub

The SAP GitHub org sap-samples contains sample code, TechEd tutorials, CodeJam material and 100s of repos from which you can learn SAP development, from ABAP to CAP to SAP Build.

  1. Go to the sap-samples org in GitHub, and check out all the sample repos to help you learn about SAP development.
  2. Watch the Developer News of Oct. 2, and learn which repo in the sap-samples org we want you to check out.
  3. Go to that repo and find the commit with the message "Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt" (NOT the merge commit). Take the commit ID and then get the 8th and 16th characters, in that order. Those are the next 2 digits of the secret code.
54

SAP Help Portal

SAP Help Portal is the main place for finding key documentation for SAP BTP services. You can now subscribe to page updates (including What's New items for the products of your choosing), get translations in about 30 languages for all documentation, content as a PDF, provide feedback, and more.

For this mission, check out 2 places on the Help Portal, and in each place you will get 2 hex digits for the secret code.

  1. First, go to the Help Portal and search for "Joule Studio". The first result will be for the product Joule Studio, the main Joule Studio documentation. On that page, find the Devtoberfest tile, which will contain your first 2 hex digits.
  2. Second, go to the SAP BTP release notes -- where you can see everything that's new for all BTP services, and you can even subscribe to receive an email whenever a new item is released in your specific service. Search for the Devtoberfest release note, and find the second set of 2 hex digits.
66

SAP Learning

SAP Learning is your first stop for learning about SAP, including tutorials and certifications for all types of development, from ABAP backend to SAP Build Apps frontend -- plus CAP, Fiori, Gen AI, Integration Suite and more.

Go to SAP Learning and then in the top menu click Browse. Select the Developer role.

Search for ABAP, and open the "SAP Certified Associate - Back-End Developer - ABAP Cloud" certification exam. This certification is for those who want to be expert in building ABAP applications based on the ABAP RESTful Application Programming (RAP) Model.

Do the following calculation:

  • Multiply the number of questions by the cut off score (between 0 and 100) by the exam time in minutes.
  • Take that number and subtract 5894.
  • Convert that number to hex, and pad with enough zeroes on the left to make it 6 digits.

Those are your hex digits for this mission.

For example, if the exam were 1 hour, with a cut off score of 50, and 35 questions, you would get the number 105,000. Subtract the number by 5894 to get 99,106 . Converting it to hex would yield 18322, and padding with zeros would yield the final answer of 018322

76

SAP Discovery Center

The SAP Discovery Center lets you explore SAP BTP services and SAP Business AI capabilities. You can see pricing, in which region each service is available, and step-by-step guides (missions) for implementing different scenarios.

Especially of note is the SAP Architecture Center, a centralized hub for SAP solution reference architectures, released in May.

This mission is divided into 2 parts, but all of it occurs inside the SAP Discovery Center.

  1. Go to the Discovery Center and search for "Joule Studio", which shows you all the missions, AI features and other artifacts related to Joule Studio.
  2. Open the "Set Up Joule Studio with SAP Build in BTP Enterprise Account" mission, which contains a project board for the task of setting up Joule Studio.
  3. On the Overview tab, you'll find the next 3 hex digits of the secret code.

Now for the second part.

  1. Go back to the Home Page of the SAP Discovery Center.
  2. Click the "SAP BTP Guidance Framework" reference architecture tile.
  3. Open "SAP Architecture Center".
  4. Browse the catalog of reference architectures and open the "Extend Joule with Joule Studio" tile, to see the reference architecture.
  5. Find the picture of Kasimir the Cat, from which you can derive the next 3 digits of the secret code. HINT: We suggest you download the picture file and take a good look at the file.

This is the toughest mission of all.

86

SAP Developers YouTube Channel

The SAP Developers YouTube channel is where you will find Antonio's videos on Integration Suite, Rekha's videos on SAP Build Process Automation, DJ's livestreams on CAP â€¦ 1200 videos in all about SAP development. Make sure to subscribe to the channel.

Go to our playlists and see all the varied content we have.

Now search for the DMS playlist (Document Management Service) and open the full playlist for DMS.

Start playing the 4th video in the playlist called "Set Up DMS with SAP Build Process Automation". A few seconds into the video, you will discover the next 6 hex digits of the secret code.

91

SAP Roadmap Explorer

The Road Map Explorer  lets you see what's being planned for your favorite SAP products. Just search for the product and then you'll see planned features for each quarter.

Go to Road Map Explorer (you will need to log in with your SAP login).

Search for Joule Studio's road map. Open any of the items and find the capability under the Capability View. The next hex digit -- just 1 digit -- is the first letter of the name of this capability.

JUST IN CASE: If for some reason you cannot log into the Roadmap Explorer, here is a second clue for the same hex digit. Go to the SAP Developer Advocates, and find the advocate who specializes in SAP Build Apps. The digit is the first letter of his/her first name.

10None (directly)

SAP Design System

The SAP Design System site shows the visual elements, UI components, and technologies that come together to build out a cohesive experience for all SAP products and  apps. Here you can explore the core building blocks that make up the SAP Design System.

For the final instructions, watch the Developer News of Oct. 16. 

Good luck!

ğŸ˜¸

entry.title: Deep Dive and Experience Sharing into SAP Joule for Developers(J4D)
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog is not written by any LLM.

Well, to start with, Joule for Developers, let us understand what it is?

Many people have a misconception that Joule for Developers or J4D is just an ABAP AI capability. But it is much more beyond ABAP. Joule for Developers(J4D) is collective name for the AI-powered design-time capabilities across SAP Build and ABAP

It includes new and existing features enabled by Joule in:

  1. SAP Build Code
  2. SAP Build Apps
  3. SAP Build Process Automation
  4. ABAP in SAP BTP and S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

These capabilities help developers build faster, code smarter, and automate better. Is that true? I will my honest opinion for some of them.

I have personally worked on SAP Build Apps, SAP Build Code and Joule for Developers, ABAP AI. I started with a lot of ambiguity and finally I made a mark that I could now explain it to our customers and users.

SAP Build Apps allow for generating pages to handle data entities and generate sample data automatically. It means, whenever you integrate any oData service/REST API/SAP BTP Destination, you get an option to automatically create the User Interface and also generate sample data.

SAP Build Code, has evolved through multiple iterations and seems it is still evolving. 

  • Created Fiori element app using Image
  • Created a series of projects with prompts
  • Created test data

With ABAP AI, I could create a report with the suggestions popping up in run time and that too contextually aware code prompts also known to be predictive code completion feature. We called it Ghost Code. But trust me sometimes they are really good too. 

I see the ABAP and CDS unit scripts getting generated in no time. It was good again on this parameter. 

Code explain, well I created small projects, hence feel it is good to have comments. But the true colors will be visible when you look at the repository of thousands lines of code written by someone and you have no clue of what it is. Using your skills you debug the code to understand what each block/function is doing. It is a life saver in this scenario.

SAP Build Code has the GenAI embedded as part of the service itself. There is no explicit step which need to perform other than just subscribing to this service via the Boosters (from the SAP BTP Global Account).

For SAP Build Apps and SAP Build Process Automation, everything under the new SAP Build Offering, will have the GenAI capability turned off by default. Then, how do you turn it on?

  1. Go to your SAP BTP Subaccount and access the SAP Build Apps and SAP Build Process Automation service from the 'Instances and Subscription' option
  2. SAP Build Lobby will openStep 1 - Access SAP Build Lobby

  3. Now go to the 'Control Tower' in the right hand side panel, last option and then click on the 'Generative AI' tile in the top row, right hand side 'Tenant Configuration'Step 2 - Click on Control Tower Option in Left Hand Pane

  4. Switch on the toggle button of Generative AI
    Step 3 - Click on Generative AI tile in the right hand pane

  5. Read the AI Terms and Conditions and scroll to the bottom of the Terms and Conditions to enable the checkbox of 'I have read the terms and conditions' - this is called as 'Scroll wrap agreement' in the language of Law - it means you agree to the Terms and Conditions and read till the last of the agreement.

    Step 5 - Read/Scroll to the end of the AI Terms & Conditions

  6. Click on the checkbox of 'I have read the terms and conditions'  

    Step 6 - Click on 'Accept' button on the right hand bottom corner

  7. Now click on the 'Accept' button 

    Step 4 - Turn on the toggle of Enable Generative AI features

  8. That's it. Now you can explore the GenAI capability inside SAP Build Apps and SAP Build Process Automation.

Some people have questions whether they need to sign a 0 USD AI Terms and Conditions contract to activate the GenAI capability for J4D. The answer is, except for 'Joule for Developers ABAP AI' capability, you do NOT need to sign an explicit contract for AI Terms and Conditions. They are all embedded within the services.

Well this will be an evolving document, where I will keep updating my reviews on each of these services mentioned. Stay tuned!

entry.title: SAP BTP for HR at SAP Connect and Success Connect 2025 summary - bigger and better than ever
entry.content:
Come see SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) at this yearâ€™s SAP Connect / Success Connect event in Las Vegas! Due to the ever-increasing interest in SAP BTP topics and our sessions in prior years having standing-room only attendance, SAP BTP has more sessions than ever before! We even have for the first time ever, not one, but two hands-on-labs!

Related: For more information about SAP BTP presence outside of HCM, see these two articles:

  • Success Connect: Your People Deserve More Than Just Software - They Deserve Success - SAP Community
  • SAP Connect 2025: The Ultimate Business Transformation Experience - SAP Community

 

SAP BTP topics for 2025

This yearâ€™s SAP BTP for HR experience at SAP Connect is all about more. More business scenarios, more technology, more platform - more BTP! This yearâ€™s topics include customer favorites such as integration, extensibility and automation as well as numerous SAP SuccessFactors product-led sessions about how SAP BTP helps them deliver better solutions making it easier for customers to streamline HCM processes. Additionally, as we see an increase in technical audience members, weâ€™ll be featuring slightly more
technical product deep dives by the product teams (also a first for us!).

Demos and hands-on labs

Demo-station demo: Automate new hire equipment ordering during onboarding, featuring Integration Suite Advanced Event Mesh

Weâ€™re showcasing two demos at the â€œIntegration and Extension with SAP BTPâ€ demo station. The first is our popular Automate new hire equipment ordering during onboarding demo which shows SAP Integration Suiteâ€™s Advanced Event Mesh event-driven integration capabilities to provide automated equipment ordering. This dramatically reduces the amount of time a people manager spends ordering equipment as well as requesting access to systems and data. If you missed this demo in Lisbon last year, then this is your chance!  Included are:

  • See how we used SAP Signavio Process Intelligence to analyze onboarding processes to identify key areas to address inefficiencies: hiring manager ordering of equipment, waiting for responses from people via email
  • SAP Integration Suite and advanced event mesh which offers real-time triggering of data synchronization based on SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central event triggers
  • An example app an IT department can create to offer pre-bundled packages of equipment to make it easier for managers to pick equipment, and to standardize offerings
  • One-click approvals by the hiring manager, powered by SAP Build 
  • Automatically submitting equipment selection to SAP Ariba guided buying via SAP Integration Suite
  • Notifications pushed to the task center for the hiring manager via SAP Build
  • Automatic submission of support tickets to SAP Service Cloud for manual tasks like requesting access to systems and data


Demo-station demo: Create a mobile app with SAP Build demo and hands-on lab

Additionally, weâ€™re showing our brand new Create a mobile app with SAP Build demo which is specifically designed for more technical HRIS audiences in collaboration with the SAP SuccessFactors team. 

This demo is also the basis of two, 75-minute hands-on labs weâ€™re offering this year which are sure to sell out! The lab will walk non-technical novices and intermediate technical knowledge people (non-developers, IT and HRIS are our target audience) on how to use SAP Build to quickly and easily create a mobile app with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central people data to offer location-specific benefits for a field office â€“ all with no coding, using SAP Buildâ€™s powerful drag-and-drop development interface. Weâ€™ll have product experts from the SAP Build team presenting and explaining to the audience the different capabilities of SAP Build in a follow-the-presenter format from their own workstations in live SAP Build environments so everyone will be able to walk away with direct product knowledge of whatâ€™s possible.
Included in the session:

  • Overview of the low-code SAP Build environment
  • Overview of various content types, controls, functions available
  • Adding content and configuring to the controls
  • Using an integration to SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central for people data
  • Accessing benefits information in the employee profile via API
  • Customizing the look and feel of the app
  • Testing the app and deployment

View the hands-on lab in the event catalog: Hands-on lab: Creating a custom mobile app for HR using SAP Build solutions (limited capacity) | HCM1677

Thereâ€™s also quick overview videos of both these demos on the SAP.com/btp-for-HR page as well!

 

SAP BTP-led sessions

Integration sessions


Maximizing HCM process efficiency with integration through SAP BTP | HCM1665

Discover how SAP Business Technology Platform and SAP Integration Suite enable integrations for SAP SuccessFactors HCM, automating tasks and processes. Explore third-party integration use cases, such as recruiting, onboarding, and data collection, and strategies for connecting hybrid landscapes, including legacy on-premises and third-party systems as well as event-driven integrations.

How to use event-driven integration to collaborate in real time | HCM1682

Explore how SAP Integration Suite advanced event mesh can use business events from SAP SuccessFactors solutions such as SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central to push data to other internal or external systems in real-time. See firsthand how you can use this capability to trigger immediate actions, such as when an employee is hired or terminated.



Application development and extensibility sessions

Increasing employee efficiency with automation capabilities in SAP BTP | HCM1671

Explore automation capabilities in SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) that can streamline your HCM processes. From recruiting and onboarding to document management, SAP BTP can help you reduce errors in manual data entry and make your employees happier by reducing repetitive and mundane tasks through automation and workflows.

Using SAP Build to extend your SAP SuccessFactors solutions | HCM1463

Standardized business processes have come a long way, but every company still has a few things it does differently from everybody else. SAP Build solutions can help extend your human capital management solutions to address your specific business needs. See firsthand how to create low-code/no-code apps that boost end-user adoption and efficiency.

 

SAP SuccessFactors-led technology sessions including SAP BTP


These SAP SuccessFactors product expert-led sessions discuss how SAP BTP solutions help SAP SuccessFactors deliver better solutions to our customers as well as ways customers may not be aware of how they can use SAP BTP today with their existing SAP SuccessFactors solutions.

 

AI Technology, use cases and innovation

Road map and vision: AI in SAP SuccessFactors HCM | HCM1451

Look at SAPâ€™s AI strategy and planned AI innovations in SAP SuccessFactors HCM. See whatâ€™s on the AI road map for HCM and get insights into SAPâ€™s responsible, real-world AI approach. AI-driven capabilities such as the Joule copilot, AI agents, and the mobile experience with Joule  enhance employee experience, adaptability, and productivity

Unlocking and extending the Joule copilot with Joule Studio | HCM1571

Experience how Joule Studioâ€¯allows you to create and deploy custom Joule agents and skills that improve efficiency across SAP and third-party systems and enhance your HR experience. Learn about prerequisites and how to get started, and find out how the agent builder capability in Joule Studio can empower you to create your own intelligent agents.

Everything you need to know about AI agents for HCM | HCM1468

AI agents are "smart teammates" that can observe, plan, and act, often without human intervention. Get a first look at some of the Joule Agents in the HCM road map, such as those for performance and goals, HR service, and people intelligence. Learn how agents can automate complex workflows, augment human capabilities, and drive efficiency.

 

 

Employee experience via integration and extensibility

Drive productivity by integrating and extending your HCM solutions | HCM1081

Discover how our recent innovations around integration and extension can help transform your business operations and enhance the user experience. You can use these technologies to integrate and extend your SAP SuccessFactors HCM portfolio with SAP Business Technology Platform.

Enhancing people profiles with SAP Business Technology Platform | HCM1520

See firsthand how you can enhance the latest people profile using SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), with an exclusive preview of advanced features slated for early adopter release in the second half of 2025. Learn how to extend people profiles to meet your organizationâ€™s needs and boost the user experience.

 

 

Technology and administration


Road map and vision: Application and technology foundation | HCM1030

Explore the latest innovations and enhancements in the technology and application foundation of SAP SuccessFactors solutions, including the SAP Business Data Cloud solution, Joule Studio, security, integration, extensibility through SAP Build solutions, and more. See demos and gain insights into what we have planned for our upcoming releases.

Simplifying your system administration to maximize business continuity | HCM1106

Explore innovative solutions to streamline system configuration and administration of your SAP SuccessFactors solutions. Gain practical tips on how your organization can modernize infrastructure management and boost efficiency with powerful administrative capabilities.

Fortifying together: Best practices for partner and customer security | HCM1061

Explore collaboration strategies and best practices for bolstering security across partners and customers. Discover how collective efforts and aligned practices can mitigate risks and build resilient ecosystems. Don't miss this opportunity to strengthen your security framework and foster trust among your business network.

 

If you havenâ€™t attended Success Connect in the past (now SAP Connect), this year is the time to come to see all the great BTP content and sessions! Learn more about SAP Connect on the event page.

entry.title: 5 Things You Didnâ€™t Know About SAP Joule for Developers â€” Plus an Exciting Update
entry.content:
Artificial intelligence is reshaping how we work, and developers are among the first to feel the impact. SAP Joule for Developers is a collection of AI capabilities in SAP Build and ABAP Environment designed to help developers build smarter, faster, and more intuitively â€” whether youâ€™re streamlining repetitive coding tasks or creating complex integrations. 

And hereâ€™s the big news: 
ğŸ‘‰The free promotion for SAP Joule for Developers has been extended. 

That means you now have even more time to explore Joule, experiment with projects, and see firsthand how it can transform your workflows â€” all at no cost. 

We are hosting an engaging webinar with demos, use cases and best practices on how to maximize value with Joule in SAP Build. Read till the end to find the registration link!

Without further ado, here are five things you might not know about SAP Joule for Developers. 

 

1. Itâ€™s More Than Just an AI Assistant 

Many developers see Joule as just a chatbot. But itâ€™s far more powerful. Joule for Developers goes beyond simple answers â€” it integrates into your workflow, generates context-aware code suggestions, and automates repetitive tasks. Whether youâ€™re building in SAP Build, working in ABAP, or connecting with third-party services, Joule is designed to keep your productivity high. 

ğŸ‘‰Learn more about capabilities via our webpage 

 

2. It Speaks â€œDeveloperâ€ Fluently 

Joule understands technical prompts and adapts its recommendations to your specific context. Describe what you want to create, and Joule can generate API calls, reusable code snippets, or even integration patterns tailored to your environment. 

ğŸ‘‰Explore a tutorial in ABAP here. 

 

3. Built-In Security and Compliance Awareness 

SAP Buildâ€”with SAP Joule for Developers embeddedâ€”is built on enterprise-grade security. It adheres to SAPâ€™s compliance standards, so your code and data are always protected. You can confidently experiment with AI in your workflows, backed by privacy, governance, and regulatory safeguards. 

ğŸ‘‰Read more about SAPâ€™s approach to security and compliance in SAP Build and SAP Business Technology Platform. 

 

4. It Helps You Learn as You Build 

Joule isnâ€™t just about solutions â€” itâ€™s about learning. As you code, Joule explains the why behind its suggestions. This helps developers discover new frameworks, understand best practices, and ramp up on unfamiliar technologies faster. 

Think of it as a mentor whoâ€™s always available, providing guidance while letting you stay in the driverâ€™s seat. 

ğŸ‘‰Try a tutorial on how to create CAP application in SAP Build. 

 

5. It Works Across Your Development Stack 

Joule isnâ€™t limited to a single tool or environment. Whether youâ€™re generating processes or building applications, SAP Joule for Developers can support you. This flexibility means you can bring AI assistance into the environments you already know â€” without having to change how you work. 

 

Free Access to SAP Joule for Developers 

Now is the best time to explore, innovate, and see how Joule can transform the way you build â€” without worrying about cost. 

ğŸ‘‰Get started today.  

ğŸ“…Mark your calendar: Join our upcoming SAP Build with Joule webinar on September 24th to see live demos, best practices, and how to maximize the value of Joule in your projects. Register here.

entry.title: SAP Build FAQ: Commercials, Getting Started and More
entry.content:
This FAQ provides an overview ofâ€¯SAPâ€™s commercial offering of SAP Build. It covers the available commercial models for SAP Build and provides answers to questions that we most often hear regarding SAP Build commercial model, onboarding, metering and more. 

What is the SAP Build Unified Offering?â€¯ 

SAP Build has been designed as the optimal way to extend SAP S/4HANA Cloud and other business applications. Thousands of customers are already experiencing up to 3x faster development speeds with SAP Build according toâ€¯recent analyst researchâ€¯â€” and now weâ€™ve made it even better. 

Combined with deep technical integration, SAP Builds unified offering empowers customers to quickly extend and personalize their business solutions using AI-powered application development and automation, while maintaining a clean core and eliminating additional licensing or budgeting complexity. 

What is included in the Unified SAP Build Offering?â€¯ 

 Customers can access the full range of SAP Build capabilities through just four distinct SKUs.  

  • SAP Build Base User is for end users who need to access applications, gain insights for day-to-day business needs, and approve tasks. 
  • SAP Build Premium User includes all the features of the base user license, with added capabilities for end users to author content, monitor processes, customize pages and deploy attended bots. 
  • SAP Build Developer includes all the features of the Premium User license, plus advanced capabilities for developers and architects who need full access to deployed assets. 
  • SAP Build Runtime Application hosting and lifecycle management services that support the creation and execution for dev/test as well as production environments 

How do I find out what is included in SAP Build?â€¯ 

  • For a list of services that are included in SAP Build you can visit the SAP Discovery Center, for SAP Build following this link 
  • To find out what is in each SKU, Base, Premium, Developer and Runtime you can visit the SAP Build Pricing Page here. 

What commercial models are SAP Build provided in?â€¯ 

Consumption Based Model:â€¯ 

  • SAP BTP Enterprise Agreement (BTPEA) 
  • SAP Cloud Enterprise Agreement (CPEA) 
  • Pay-As-You-Go for SAP BTP 

Subscription Based Commercial Mode:â€¯ 

  • Service Plan for SAP Build Subscription 

SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition:â€¯ 

  • SAP Build Entitlements are included in the SAP Cloud ERP Edition 
  • Find more about SAP Cloud ERP Edition hereâ€¯â€¯ 
  • Find out more about the SAP Build offering in SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition here 

SAP Business Suite Packages: 

  • Entitlements are provided in several of the SAP Business Suite packages 

Partner: 

  • SAP Build offers partners free access to SAP Build and other BTP Services. 
  • SAP Build Test, Demo Development (the site requires you to be logged in as an SAP Partner) 
     

How do I get started with SAP Build?â€¯ 

SAP Build uses SAP BTPs Cloud Integration Automation (CIA) to quickly get customers and partners up and going on SAP Build.  Find information on how to setup SAP Build here.  For detailed instructions on the activation process, please share this blog post with your technical team 

Does SAP Build include Joule Studio and Joule for Developer?â€¯â€¯ 

Yes, SAP Build provides Joule for Developer and Joule Studio.  Joule Studio is provided with the SAP Build Developer offering.  Joule for Developer features are included, but will need to enable this through the free voucher SKUs.  You can find more information on Joule for Developer here and Joule Studio here. 

Are there specific service plans that are exclusive to the unified SAP Build offering? 

The Joule Studio service is only offered in the SAP Build Developer SKU. Joule for Developer needs to be enabled through the free voucher SKU's and then can only be used with the SAP Build offering, SAP Build Code and Joule for Developer, BTP ABAP Environment.  Visual Cloud Functions in SAP Build Apps is not available in the SAP Build unified SKU. 

Can I migrate from the previous SAP Build SKUâ€™s to the new SAP Build SKU?â€¯ 
 
Upgrade you SAP Build licenses to access enhanced features and tools.  Use build-specific plans for improved efficiently and customization in your projects.   

For migration of services please refer to this help 

 Can I use both the Old and New Service plans within the same subaccount? 

 The old services cannot be enabled in the same subaccount as the new Build services.  You will need to do a migration per the above migration guide. 

 How does metering work, for example if I use both SAP Build Base User and SAP Build Developer capabilities? 

SAP Build operates on a metering model that relies on specific user roles to determine access and functionality within the platform, which include developer, base user, and premium user. Each user must have a global user ID created by an administrator, who also assigns the appropriate role collection to ensure that the correct authorization is granted. 

This role assignment is critical; for instance, an SAP Build base user shouldn't be able to create new processes within SAP Build, as such permissions could lead to unintended alterations or disruptions in workflows. By understanding and correctly implementing these roles, organizations can effectively manage user capabilities while maintaining the integrity and security of their SAP Build environment. 

For more detailed information on metering and roles visit this help location. 

 How can I learn more about SAP Build?â€¯ 

  •  SAP Build Basic Trialâ€“Get hands-on experience with a free, 30-day trial, following a step-by-step tutorial on SAP Build. 
  • SAP Discovery Centerâ€“Dive deeper with step-by-step guidance and best practices for implementing use cases.  
  • SAP Learning â€“Develop SAP skills for free, anywhere, anytime, and at your own pace: SAP Build

entry.title: Unlocking the Power of SAP Build (SAP Build Bootcamp for Partners)
entry.content:
On September 18th, we conducted a session focused on the new SAP Build and how it can be an element of transformation enabeling innovation, automation, and extensibility. From a packed agenda, expert Q&A and networking; the participants had first-hand views on how the new SAP Build (and assets like Joule, ABAP RAP, and BTP AI Core) can be used as a differentiator and how organizations can leverage them to build and extend SAP solutions.
